sen.j: 小槻氏（おづきし/おつきし）は、古代から続く公家の氏族。
sen.e: The Ozuki (or Otsuki) clan is a clan of kuge (court noble) which has lasted since ancient times.
The Ozuki (or Otsuki) clan is a clan of kuge (court nobles) which can trace its history back to ancient times.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: The Ozuki (Otsuki) was a Kuge (court nobles) clan which could trace its history back to ancient times.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 鎌倉時代まで本姓である小槻氏を称すが、その後は分裂し、それぞれ家名（苗字）である壬生家壬生家（小槻姓）・大宮家大宮家（小槻氏）・虫鹿家・村田家を称した。
sen.e: Until the Kamakura period, it used the legal family name, Ozuki clan, but it split after that and began to use each family name of the Mibu family (the family name of Ozuki), the Omiya family (the Ozuki clan), the Mushika family and the Murata family.
Until the Kamakura period, the clan used the name of Ozuki, but then divided to become the Mibu family (Ozuki family), the Omiya family (the Ozuki clan), the Mushika family and the Murata family.
sen.cmt: Not sure how to translate the repeated names of 壬生家壬生家 and 宮家大宮家. Also, the meaning of 小槻姓 in this context is not clear to me.
sen.e: Up to the Kamakura period, the clan went under their original surname Ozuki, but thereafter it was divided into the Mibu, Omiya, Mushika, and Murata families.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 第11代垂仁天皇の皇子、意知別命を祖とするとされる。
sen.e: It is regarded to be originated from Ochiwake no mikoto, the prince of the 11th Emperor Suinin.
The Ozuki clan seems to have orginated with Ochiwake no Mikoto an Imperial Prince descended from Emperor Suinin, the 11th Emperor.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: The Ozuki clan is believed to have originated with OCHIWAKE no Mikoto, an Imperial Prince of the eleventh Emperor Suinin.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。11thスペルアウトしました。

sen.j: 子孫は小月山公（小槻山君、おつきのやまのきみ）を称すが、その後875年、小槻今雄（小槻氏祖）に対して阿保朝臣の氏姓を与えられる。
sen.e: The descendant used the name of Otsuki yama no kimi, but in 875 OZUKI no Imao (the founder of the Ozuki clan) was given the surname of Abo ason.
The descendants of Ochiwake no Mikoto used the name of Otsuki yama no kimi, but in 875 OZUKI no Imao (the founder of the Ozuki clan) was given the surname of Abo ason.
sen.cmt: Here, OZUKI no Imao is mentioned as the founder of the Ozuki clan. However, in 10, the Ozuki clan is said to "be originated from Ochiwake.." Which is it??
sen.e: The descendants of OCHIWAKE no Mikoto had used the name of OTSUKI no Yama no kimi until 875 when Imao (the founder of the Ozuki clan) was given the surname of Abo ason (second highest of the eight hereditary titles).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 子小槻当平（まさひら）のとき、本拠地であった近江国栗太郡小槻の地名にちなみ小槻宿禰に改め、以後禰家とも呼ばれた。
sen.e: His son Masahira OZUKI changed the name as Ozuki no sukune after the place name of its home town, Ozuki, Kurita-gun, Omi Province, and after that, it had been called the Ne family as well (in the Kurita-gun, there remain Otsuki Taisha Shrine and Otsuki-jinja Shrine still now).

OZUKI no Imao's son Masahira OZUKI changed the name to Ozuki no Sukune after the name of its home town, Ozuki, Kurita-gun, Omi Provincem and, thereafter, the clan also went by the name of Ne family (using the last character in Sukune) (in Kurita-gun, Otsuki Taisha Shrine and Otsuki-jinja Shrine can still be seen today).
sen.cmt: The explanation is confusing here. The name OZUKI was already being used before it "changed the name as Ozuki no sukune after the place name of its home town".
sen.e: Imao's son Masahira changed the name to Ozuki no Sukune after their home town Ozuki, Kurita-gun, Omi Province (present-day Shiga Prefecture) and thereafter the clan also went by the name of the Ne family (using the last character in Sukune).
sen.cmt: FBに基いて修正しました。一原文一訳文例外処理

sen.j: （栗太郡地域には現在も小槻大社・小槻神社が残る。）
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: (The Otsuki Taisha Shrine and the Otsuki-jinja Shrine still stand in Kurita-gun region today.)
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文例外処理

sen.j: 以後小槻氏は代々官人としての職を担い、地下家筆頭の地位を得る。
sen.e: After that, the Ozuki clan had worked as government official (esp. one of low to medium rank) successively and got the status of the top of Jige-ke (family status of non-noble retainers who are not allowed into the Emperor's living quarters in the imperial palace).

Thereafter, generations of the Ozuki clan served as government officials (esp. ones of low to medium rank), reaching the status of top Jige-ke (non-noble retainers who are not allowed into the Emperor's living quarters in the imperial palace).
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Thereafter, generations of the Ozuki clan served as government officials (esp. ones of low to medium rank) and finally reached to the status of top Jige-ke (non-noble retainers who are not allowed into the Emperor's living quarters in the imperial palace).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 鎌倉時代初期に小槻隆職子孫の壬生家壬生家（小槻姓）と小槻広房子孫の大宮家大宮家（小槻氏）に分裂。
sen.e: At the beginning of the Kamakura period, it split into the Mibu family (the family name was Ozuki), the descendant of OTSUKI no Takamoto, and the Omiya family (the Ozuki clan), the descendant of OZUKI no Hirofusa.

At the beginning of the Kamakura period, the clan split into the Mibu family (Ozuki family), the descendant of OZUKI no Takamoto, and the Omiya family (the Ozuki clan), the descendant of OZUKI no Hirofusa.
sen.cmt: It is not clear to me what is meant by 壬生家壬生家（小槻姓）. In trans1 "Mibu family (the family name was Ozuki)" is confusing - surely the family name of the Mibu family was "Mibu"!
sen.e: In the early Kamakura period, the clan split into the Mibu family, the descendants of OZUKI no Takamoto, and the Omiya family, the descendants of OZUKI no Hirofusa.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 両家は互いに地位を争うも、1551年大宮家が大宮伊治のときに断絶したため、それから後は壬生家壬生家（小槻姓）が明治維新まで官人の職を果たす。
sen.e: They had vied for the post each other, but since the lineage of the Omiya family was broken when Koreharu OMIYA died in 1551, the Mibu family (the family name was Ozuki) had put in charge of government official until the Meiji Restoration.

The two families initially vied with each other for position, but the lineage of the Omiya family was broken when Koreharu OMIYA died in 1551 while the Mibu family (Ozuki family) continued to occupy positions in government official until the Meiji Restoration.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: The two families initially vied with each other for position, but the Omiya family ceased to exist when Koreharu OMIYA died in 1551 while the Mibu family kept positions of government official until the Meiji Restoration.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 他に庶家として、室町時代に虫鹿家が大宮家大宮家（小槻氏）から、江戸時代に村田家が壬生家壬生家（小槻姓）から分裂した。
sen.e: The other branch families are the Mushika family separated from the Omiya family (the Ozuki clan) in the Muromachi period and the Murata family (the family name was Ozuki) separated from the Mibu family in the Edo period.

The other branch families are the Mushika family which separated from the Omiya family (Ozuki clan) in the Muromachi period and the Murata family which separated from the Mibu family (Ozuki family) in the Edo period.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: The other branch families include the Mushika family separated from the Omiya family in the Muromachi period and the Murata family from the Mibu family in the Edo period.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 維新後、壬生家壬生家（小槻姓）は男爵との爵位を与えられた。
sen.e: After the Meiji Restoration, the Mibu family (the family name was Ozuki) was given the status of baron.
After the Meiji Restoration, the Mibu family (Ozuki family) was awarded the title of baron.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: After the Meiji Restoration, the title of baron the was bestowed on the Mibu family.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 今雄が左少史兼算博士の職を与えられた後、853年平安京に移住を許され、名実ともに官人となった。
sen.e: After Imao was given the duty of Sashoshi (assistant recorder of the left) and sanhakase (a position teaching mathematics and growing mathematicians), he was allowed to move to Heian-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Kyoto) in 853 and became the government official both in name and reality.

After Imao was appointed Sashoshi (assistant recorder of the left) and sanhakase (charged with teaching mathematics and looking after mathematicians), he was allowed to move to Heian-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan at present-day Kyoto) in 853 and became a government official both in name and reality.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: After appointed as Sashoshi (assistant recorder of the left) and Sanhakase (official in charge of teaching mathematics and looking after mathematicians), Imao was allowed to move to Heian-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan at present-day Kyoto) in 853 and became a government official both in name and reality.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 以後小槻氏は算博士と史 (律令制)の職を世襲する。
sen.e: After that, the Ozuki clan had succeeded the official duties of sanhakase and shi (a recorder in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code)).

Thereafter, members of the Ozuki clan inherited the positions of sanhakase and shi (recorder in the Ritsuryo system, a system of centralized government based on the Ritsuryo code, a law system based on Confucianism)).
sen.cmt: Added further explanation of "Ritusryo code"
sen.e: Thereafter, members of the Ozuki clan inherited the positions of Sanhakase and Shi (official in charge of recording and managing the official documents).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 996年小槻奉親が左大史（大夫史）に任命されたのを皮切りに次第に左大史に任ぜられることが多くなった。
sen.e: After OZUKI no Tomochika was assigned to Sashoshi (Taifu no shi (senior recorder with the junior fifth rank, lower grade)) in 996, gradually it had been assigned to Sashoshi more often and succeeded it by heredityafter Takanobu OZUKI around the eleventh centuries, which established the status as the Kanmu family who governed benkan (officials of the dajokan) and controlled official works of the government.

After OZUKI no Tomochika was appointed Sashoshi (Taifu no shi (senior recorder of junior fifth rank, lower grade)) in 996, the Ozuki clan came to appointed as Sashoshi more often. The Ozuki clan gained hereditary control over the position afterTakanobu OZUKI in the eleventh century, solidifying their status as a Kanmu family with authority over benkan (officials of the dajokan) and official works of the government.
sen.cmt: Split into two sentences.
sen.e: After OZUKI no Tomochika was appointed to the position of Sadaishi (Taifu no shi (senior recorder of Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade)) in 996, many other members of the Ozuki clan were appointed to the position.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文例外処理

sen.j: 11世紀頃小槻孝信の代からは世襲となって、弁官を取り仕切り官中を統轄する官務家としての地位を確立した。
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Since the generation of OZUKI no Takanobu in the eleventh century, the Ozuki clan gained hereditary control over the position and solidified their status as a Kanmu family with authority over benkan (officials of the dajokan) and official works of the government.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文例外処理

sen.j: 他に、主殿寮や採銅所の管理などを行っていた。
sen.e: In addition, the Ozuki clan managed Tonomoryo (Imperial Palace Keeper's Bureau) and the copper mines.
sen.cmt: Natural English. 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: In addition, the Ozuki clan managed Tonomoryo (Imperial Palace Keeper's Bureau) and the copper mines.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: また、宮中の文書の保管にあたっていたため、現在に「壬生家文書」が残る。
sen.e: Moreover, since it was in charge of keeping documents of the Imperial court, there remains 'Mibuke Monjo (documents of the Mibu family)' today.
Also, since the Ozuki clan was in charge of keeping documents of the Imperial court, 'Mibuke Monjo (documents of the Mibu family)' are still in existence today.
sen.cmt: I can't follow the logic of this sentence. Why does the fact that this family kept documents of the Imperial court means that the documents are still in existence today. Further explanation is required.
sen.e: Since the Ozuki clan was in charge of storing documents of the Imperial court, 'Mibuke Monjo' (documents of the Mibu family) are still in existence today.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。
